adverb.description: To a higher degree than is desirable, permissible, or possible; excessively.
examples: he wore suits that seemed a size too small for him

phrases: It was mayhem, fuelled by bar staff and a pub industry all too willing to serve drink after drink after drink.
Secondly, they may recall or understand all too well but deliberately dissemble.
Despite the change in the law regarding this action, this sight is still all too common.
Brief moments of brilliance gave the crowd room for cheer but it was all too fleeting.
origin: Old English, stressed form of to, spelled too from the 16th century.
